summary: This is a status update memorandum from the DOJ Office of the Inspector General to the Federal Bureau of Prisons regarding the implementation of recommendations from the OIG's final report on the custody, care, and supervision of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. It details the BOP's responses to eight recommendations aimed at improving suicide prevention, inmate monitoring, staffing, and security camera systems.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The deceased inmate whose custody and death at the Metropolitan Correctional Center prompted the original OIG investigation and the subsequent policy recommendations.

events.title: OIG Final Report Release
events.description: The Department of Justice Office of the Inspector General issued its final report on the investigation and review of the BOP's custody, care, and supervision of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

events.title: BOP Status Update Submission
events.description: The Federal Bureau of Prisons submitted a status update to the OIG in response to the recommendations from the June 2023 final report.

events.title: BOP Incentives Reduction
events.description: The BOP reported that due to budgetary constraints, it is reducing or eliminating the use of staffing incentives effective this date.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York, New York
keyFacts: The OIG's 2023 report made eight recommendations to the BOP following its investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's custody and death; one recommendation was previously closed, and the remaining seven are currently 'Resolved' pending final policy implementation.

The BOP is in the process of revising multiple Program Statements (5321.09, 5324.08, 5500.14, 4200.12) to address recommendations on cellmate assignment, suicide watch procedures, inmate monitoring, and security camera systems, but these revisions are subject to union negotiation.

The BOP reported notable improvements in staff retention rates (overall and for Correctional Officers and Nurse Practitioners) due to incentives outlined in a 2023 'Incentives Playbook,' but is now reducing or eliminating those incentives due to budgetary constraints as of March 23, 2025.

The BOP has requested over $1.5 billion in funding from Congress to increase Correctional Officer positions by 4,500 and nurse positions by 200 over the next five years, based on projections from a new Automated Staffing Tool.

The OIG will not close the recommendations until the BOP finalizes the referenced policy revisions and provides them for OIG review, and provides further updates on staffing incentives, congressional reports, and salary proposals to OPM.
